articles.headline: Who Cancels Lunch With Warren Buffett? A Chinese Tycoon Did, but Why?
articles.snippet: Justin Sun denied reports that he had postponed a charity lunch with the investing guru after attracting regulatory scrutiny. In China, where executives sometimes vanish, such reports are not unusual.
articles.abstract: Justin Sun denied reports that he had postponed a charity lunch with the investing guru after attracting regulatory scrutiny. In China, where executives sometimes vanish, such reports are not unusual.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Everybody knew where Justin Sun, a brash Chinese millionaire and cryptocurrency celebrity, was going to be this week. He had paid a record $4.6 million to have a charity lunch with Warren Buffett, the investing guru, in San Francisco, and he was counting down the days on social media.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: Facebook Antitrust Inquiry Shows Big Tech’s Freewheeling Era Is Past
articles.snippet: Two settlements and a new antitrust investigation highlighted a new reality for tech giants: Scrutiny from regulators and lawmakers has become a constant.
articles.abstract: Two settlements and a new antitrust investigation highlighted a new reality for tech giants: Scrutiny from regulators and lawmakers has become a constant.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook came under siege on multiple fronts on Wednesday, agreeing to new layers of oversight and two fines to settle privacy and disclosure violations, even as it acknowledged that it was under investigation from the Federal Trade Commission for antitrust concerns.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Mueller Warns of Russian Sabotage and Rejects Trump’s ‘Witch Hunt’ Claims
articles.snippet: Robert S. Mueller III laid out damning insights about President Trump, calling his responses to investigators untruthful and acknowledging that he could later be charged with a crime.
articles.abstract: Robert S. Mueller III laid out damning insights about President Trump, calling his responses to investigators untruthful and acknowledging that he could later be charged with a crime.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Mueller III warned lawmakers on Wednesday that Russia was again trying to sabotage American democracy before next year’s presidential election, defended his investigation’s conclusions about Moscow’s sweeping interference campaign in 2016 and publicly rejected President Trump’s criticism that he had conducted a “witch hunt.”

articles.headline: Mueller’s Labored Performance Was a Departure From His Once-Fabled Stamina
articles.snippet: As special counsel, Mr. Mueller adopted a more hands-off style than when he was F.B.I. director, and it was on display Wednesday in his congressional appearances.
articles.abstract: As special counsel, Mr. Mueller adopted a more hands-off style than when he was F.B.I. director, and it was on display Wednesday in his congressional appearances.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Soon after the special counsel’s office opened in 2017, some aides noticed that Robert S. Mueller III kept noticeably shorter hours than he had as F.B.I. director, when he showed up at the bureau daily at 6 a.m. and often worked nights.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Michael S. Schmidt, Noah Weiland and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Ricardo Rosselló, Puerto Rico’s Governor, Resigns After Protests
articles.snippet: Mr. Rosselló announced his resignation on Wednesday after widespread protests and looming impeachment proceedings derailed his administration.
articles.abstract: Mr. Rosselló announced his resignation on Wednesday after widespread protests and looming impeachment proceedings derailed his administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló of Puerto Rico announced his resignation on Wednesday night, conceding that he could no longer credibly remain in power after an extraordinary popular uprising and looming impeachment proceedings had derailed his administration.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles

articles.headline: The Blockbuster That Wasn’t: Mueller Disappoints the Democrats
articles.snippet: Robert S. Mueller III’s testimony to Congress about the Russia investigation failed to provide the dramatic moment that President Trump’s critics wanted.
articles.abstract: Robert S. Mueller III’s testimony to Congress about the Russia investigation failed to provide the dramatic moment that President Trump’s critics wanted.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the days leading up to the special counsel’s much-anticipated appearance before Congress, Democrats argued that hearing from Robert S. Mueller III on television could transform the impeachment debate. While Americans might not read the book, the argument went, they would watch the movie.

articles.headline: Calls Mount to Ease Big Tech’s Grip on Your Data
articles.snippet: The wealth of some tech giants is built on harvesting and commercializing personal data. Advocates for a new deal on data are gaining momentum.
articles.abstract: The wealth of some tech giants is built on harvesting and commercializing personal data. Advocates for a new deal on data are gaining momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: The market for our digital data can seem like a lopsided bargain.

articles.headline: Nissan Will Cut 12,500 Jobs, and Its Chief Hints at Leaving
articles.snippet: The Japanese carmaker’s profit plunge suggests its problems run deeper than it has said, putting more pressure on it to fix its alliance with Renault.
articles.abstract: The Japanese carmaker’s profit plunge suggests its problems run deeper than it has said, putting more pressure on it to fix its alliance with Renault.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — Nissan on Thursday said it had begun cutting more than 12,500 jobs around the world after its profitability essentially evaporated in its most recent quarter.

articles.headline: Ad Tool Facebook Built to Fight Disinformation Doesn’t Work as Advertised
articles.snippet: The social network’s new ad library is so flawed, researchers say, that it is effectively useless as a way to track political messaging.
articles.abstract: The social network’s new ad library is so flawed, researchers say, that it is effectively useless as a way to track political messaging.
articles.lead_paragraph: Faced with a rising backlash over the spread of disinformation in the aftermath of the 2016 elections, Facebook last year came up with a seemingly straightforward solution: It created an online library of all the advertisements on the social network.

articles.headline: Puerto Rico Governor Misread Anger Brewing Against Him
articles.snippet: Ricardo Rosselló had a close circle of associates who shared advice and friendship. But critics said the Puerto Rico governor became too isolated from others.
articles.abstract: Ricardo Rosselló had a close circle of associates who shared advice and friendship. But critics said the Puerto Rico governor became too isolated from others.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The people of Puerto Rico knew him first as Ricky, the handsome boy who moved into the governor’s residence when he was just 13. His father was the governor, and Ricardo A. Rosselló grew up as a child of privilege in historic La Fortaleza, a palatial 16th-century mansion with heavy drapes and thick wooden doors just steps from San Juan Bay.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Is Peak TV Really a Bonanza for Female Comics? That’s a Laugh
articles.snippet: The streaming era is thought to be a golden age for women. But for Kate Micucci and many of her peers, the reality is much more complicated.
articles.abstract: The streaming era is thought to be a golden age for women. But for Kate Micucci and many of her peers, the reality is much more complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: One morning last fall in Los Angeles, the comic and actress Kate Micucci sat chewing over a pitch for a television series with her writing partner, Felicia Day. How conventional would the gender roles have to be, they wondered, before a studio would bite?

articles.headline: A Heat Wave Bakes Europe, Where Air-Conditioning Is Scarce
articles.snippet: Temperatures broke records, but while air-conditioning use is up among Europeans, it remains far less common than elsewhere in the world.
articles.abstract: Temperatures broke records, but while air-conditioning use is up among Europeans, it remains far less common than elsewhere in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Never in recorded history has Paris been hotter than it was on Thursday, when the temperature neared 110 degrees. The same was true of Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands, as a dangerous heat wave scorched Western Europe.
articles.byline: By Iliana Magra, Elian Peltier and Constant Méheut

articles.headline: U.S. to Resume Capital Punishment for Federal Inmates on Death Row
articles.snippet: The federal government has not executed anyone since 2003, but the attorney general announced that five inmates will be put to death starting in December.
articles.abstract: The federal government has not executed anyone since 2003, but the attorney general announced that five inmates will be put to death starting in December.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government will resume executions of death row inmates after a nearly two-decade hiatus, Attorney General William P. Barr said Thursday, countering a broad national shift away from the death penalty as public support for capital punishment has dwindled.
